title: Unilateral combination of small doughs
vignette: Two neighbours each have less than the threshold that obligates dough-offering. One quietly kneads both portions together, pushing the total above the limit. Must dough offering now be separated from both portions?

options.text: Yes; combining doughs creates a joint liability to give dough offering.
No; each owner is liable only for her own initial portion.

title: Dividing after kneading to avoid the set aside a portion
vignette: A household kneads a large batch, then splits it into sub-loaves each below the threshold, hoping to escape the dough offering obligation. Is the stratagem valid?

options.text: Stratagem fails; obligation fixed at kneading.
Stratagem works; final loaf size determines liability.

title: Accepting dough from a non-Jewish baker
vignette: A Jew buys raw dough from a non-member who already kneaded it. Must the buyer separate dough offering now, or is the batch exempt?

options.text: Obligated once the Jew acquires; ownership triggers moral obligation.
Exempt; obligation rests on the kneader, not the purchaser.

title: Size of the Community Elder’s share – home cook vs. commercial bakery
vignette: foundational document leaves the dough offering amount undefined. Should a home cook give 1/24 of the dough while an industrial baker gives only 1/48, or should there be a single uniform rate?

options.text: Differentiate – larger share from households, smaller from bakeries.
Uniform minimal share for all; treat everyone equally.

title: Handling Dough Offering that became ritually contaminated
vignette: Separated dough offering turns contaminated and may not be eaten by a community elder. May the owner feed it to dogs, or must it be burned?

options.text: Burn it; food with special status must not be desecrated.
Feed to animals; better utilitarian use than waste.

title: Exporting Dough Offering from the Communities Abroad to The Homeland
vignette: communities abroad Jews (where dough offering is by community rule) wish to send their separated portion to community elders in the homeland. Is the extra logistic cost obligatory altruism or needless?

options.text: Send it; honouring the community elder gift overrides inconvenience.
Keep/discard locally; no duty to incur shipping expense.

title: Mixtures of species and obligation
vignette: Barley dough (liable) is mixed with rice dough (exempt), reducing the ratio below majority. Does the mixture now require dough offering?

options.text: Yes; any amount of liable grain triggers dough offering.
No; sub-majority of liable grain is annulled.
